image.altText: A close up shot of a tanned man, gray hair, black-framed glasses, plaid pattern button up shirt.

props.synopsis: Central Land Council chief executive Lesley Turner — who is suing Jacinta Nampijinpa Price for defamation — testifies in Federal Court, and denies being "embarrassed" by the senator pointing out alleged "failures" of the council.

title.children: Land council boss testifies against Senator Nampijinpa Price in defamation trial

image.altText: A woman with glasses speaking to the media.

props.synopsis: The NT attorney-general's department has taken the extraordinary step of releasing private emails between a top judge and bureaucrats, to try and address allegations of interference.

title.children: NT attorney-general's department releases private emails with top judge

image.altText: A group of Aboriginal mourners walking through a coles supermarket, while holding branches.

props.synopsis: Supermarket giant Coles is among the parties expected to take part in a coronial inquest into the death in custody of a young Aboriginal man inside its Alice Springs shop earlier this year.

title.children: Coles to appear at death in custody inquest, as family calls for answers

image.altText: Beryl sits outside in the sunlight in front of a tree, looking at the camera with an inscrutable expression.

props.synopsis: As the Northern Territory prison population continues to reach all-time highs, data reveals a majority of the NT's rehab program are being cancelled more often than they are being delivered.

title.children: NT prisons so crammed 'girls are sleeping at reception'

image.altText: Men in white coats looking at beef carcasses inside an abattoir.

props.synopsis: A cattle company in Western Australia's Kimberley has struck a deal with a Northern Territory abattoir to get local beef to consumers in remote communities.

title.children: Indigenous cattle company supplying affordable beef to remote areas

image.altText: A women with short dark hair and glasses looks seriously at the camera.

props.synopsis: IUDs can be inserted by GPs, gynaecologists and family planning doctors, but in Alice Springs there aren't enough local professionals trained to do so.

title.children: Women waiting months, considering interstate travel for birth control

image.altText: A close up on a hand holding a mobile phone with two betting company brands visible on the screen.

props.synopsis: More than 40 of Australia's corporate bookmakers are based in the Northern Territory for its low taxes and what critics describe as weak regulation.

title.children: Calls for inquiry into Australia's de facto online gambling regulator

image.altText: Various images of two men partipacting in a local parkrun in Karratha, WA.

props.synopsis: Shaded and green spaces can be hard to find in northern towns and cities where summer temperatures regularly surpass 40 degrees Celsius.

title.children: Climate adaptation 'shortfall' exposes vulnerability to hotter temperatures

image.altText: 3x3 Widest

props.synopsis: After former principal Gavin Morris was found guilty on four counts of aggravated assault, pressure is growing to explain a confidential 2024 assessment of Yipirinya School.

title.children: Calls mount to explain Yipirinya School review after ex-principal found guilty

image.altText: A woman with long brown hair speaking while looking off camera.

props.synopsis: Senator Lidia Thorpe refers Northern Territory's attorney-general to the corruption watchdog after allegations of government interference in the NT Supreme Court's media activities that were later deemed "a misunderstanding".

title.children: Lidia Thorpe refers NT attorney-general to corruption watchdog

image.altText: A black and white image of viper biting into a gel cylinder, a tiled background.

props.synopsis: Dozens of species of snakes have been captured on high-speed cameras, with researchers finding vipers were the fastest, but an Australian snake was not far behind.

title.children: Snakes can strike faster than your brain tells your muscles to move

image.altText: Minister for Environment Murray Watt speaking.

props.synopsis: Environment Minister Murray Watt links the passage of Labor's Environmental Protection Reform Bill to critical minerals, housing and renewable energy projects.

title.children: Minister says critical minerals, housing will suffer if environment laws aren't passed

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Greens open to negotiating with Labor on environmental protection reforms
Murray Watt says government is open to amendments on environment bill
Kevin Rudd did a 'good job' on critical minerals deal: Jane Hume

image.altText: A submarine at the surface with morning sun on its right flank, the ocean stretches behind it

props.synopsis: In Washington on Monday, Anthony Albanese made something clear once again: Australia is all-in on the trilateral defence pact. Clarifying what US powerbrokers think remains a multi-billion-dollar question.

title.children: Australia is all in on AUKUS. In Donald Trump's America, it's more complicated

image.altText: An old book tearing at the seams.

props.synopsis: There are many factors that can determine the monetary value of a book, so what can make an edition worth tens of thousands of dollars?

title.children: $40k price tag on The Hobbit raises hopes for other rare books

image.altText: A man being led by police.

props.synopsis: Police allege three men falsely claimed to be mediating between a construction company and unions to prevent disruptions at buildings sites.

title.children: Three men charged with alleged $6.6 million construction extortion

image.altText: Two men are holding a fabric with a camouflage military pattern inside a factory.

props.synopsis: As US President Donald Trump visits South-East Asia amid global trade tensions, Indonesian exporters worry the region could bear the brunt of his protectionist policies.

title.children: Trump's tariffs would change this city once known as Indonesia’s textile hub

image.altText: Girls in traditional dress smiling on a stage

props.synopsis: A native title claim in the region where Captain James Cook made landfall after his ship crashed into the Great Barrier Reef in 1770 is among one of three to finally be settled by the Federal Court this week.

title.children: Cape York land returned to owners 255 years after Captain James Cook arrived

image.altText: A low angle shot of a black bike seat with a woman standing behind, back to the camera.

props.synopsis: "Saddle soreness" is a common complaint among cyclists. These innovators are looking at creative ways to prevent it by redesigning the bike seat.

title.children: Could a new bike seat prevent saddle pain? These innovators think so

image.altText: Three people playing cricket on the dish

props.synopsis: The film The Dish helped reintroduce a new generation of Australians to the critical role the Parkes Observatory played in the Moon landing. Twenty-five years after its release, the film has had a lasting impact.

title.children: How the Dish catapulted a rural observatory to international fame

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market is poised to open higher on Friday, following gains on Wall Street. Investor sentiment has been buoyed by news that Donald Trump plans to meet with Xi Jinping, while US sanctions on Russia have pushed oil prices higher. Follow live.

title.children: ASX set to rise, Wall Street, Trump to meet Xi, oil bounces

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Apple loses UK tribunal case over ‘excessive’ App Store fees

image.altText: GettyImages-2178235912

props.synopsis: Kenya's Ruth Chepngetich is banned from athletics for three years over a doping violation.

title.children: Marathon world record-holder banned for three years over doping violation

image.altText: A black object on a dusty red dirt road.

props.synopsis: How closely were you following the news this week? Test yourself to find out!

title.children: ABC news quiz: A jewel heist, an awkward Trump moment and a mysterious burning object in the outback

image.altText: Black and white image of toddler with fair hair in front of tree

props.synopsis: NSW MP Jeremy Buckingham used parliamentary privilege to read a 1971 confession in the Cheryl Grimmer case, bypassing decades of legal silence. Outside parliament, the man's identity remains legally suppressed.

title.children: Privilege reveals Grimmer confession, but legal restrictions remain

image.altText: A young female Paralympian holding flower while celebrating winning a silver medal

props.synopsis: Sydney 2000 was a turning point — not just for me, but for the entire Paralympic movement, writes silver medallist Elizabeth Wright.

title.children: Winning a silver medal at the Sydney Paralympics changed everything

image.altText: A dolphin in the ocean with a brown sea sponge on it.

props.synopsis: Scientists observe male humpback dolphins parading sea sponges on their heads to impress females off Western Australia's northern coast.

title.children: Male dolphins spotted donning sea-sponge wigs to attract females

image.altText: A sign at the University of Adelaide.

props.synopsis: The vice-chancellor of the University of Adelaide says the underpayments, which occurred between 2017 and 2025, were "unfortunate and very regrettable".

title.children: University of Adelaide uncovers $1.25m underpayment of more than 800 staff

image.altText: The front facade of an art deco style cinema

props.synopsis: After sitting idle for two decades residents of the NSW town of Mudgee have purchased the iconic Regent Theatre, with plans to return it to its former glory.

title.children: 'Upset' locals decide to buy mothballed theatre

image.altText: A man looks at the camera with a serious expression, with trees in the background.

props.synopsis: Lueth Akue turned to crime during a childhood plagued by hardship. He is using his experience to help young offenders turn their lives around in Australia's "crime capital".

title.children: Former offenders work to turn young people away from crime

image.altText: A construction worker wearing hi-vis looking at a crane and buildings.

props.synopsis: The Queensland government has announced a pilot program which would subsidies the wages of about 7 per cent of the state's apprentices if taken on by eligible businesses.

title.children: Small businesses say taking on apprentices a financial challenge

image.altText: Group of four women stand together

props.synopsis: The program from the Women's and Girls' Emergency Centre helps pregnant women in, or at risk of incarceration find safe accommodation and keep families together.

title.children: The program helping women facing jail have their babies in the community

image.altText: Three women sit under a shady tree on a limestone wall. From left to right wearing a dress, collard shirt, tshirt with hat.

props.synopsis: Jessie Carrie could not find the support she needed after being diagnosed with ADHD as an adult, so she started groups to help others.

title.children: Support groups helping connect women diagnosed with ADHD later in life

image.altText: A bird with green grass stems on its face on a windy day

props.synopsis: The 40 shortlisted images pair talented nature photography with humour that often relies on clicking the shutter at just the right moment.

title.children: In need of a laugh? Check out the finalists of the Comedy Wildlife Photo Awards

image.altText: Sussan Ley

props.synopsis: Optimism that a deal can be found to amend Australia's environment laws fades, as the Coalition raises concerns over details just days after parts of the legislation were shared with stakeholders.

title.children: Coalition sours over proposed reform to 'broken' environment laws

image.altText: Woman in high vis shirt using drill

props.synopsis: Experts say unlocking flexible hours, gender diversity and migrant workers could help Australia meet its housing targets.

title.children: Women could be future of construction but 'industry is not designed' for them
